natural solution: We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta \begin{vmatrix} \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[cos(alpha) * cos(beta), cos(alpha) * sin(beta), -sin(alpha)], 
[-sin(beta), cos(beta), 0], 
[sin(alpha) * cos(beta), sin(alpha) * sin(beta), cos(alpha)]]) = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta \begin{vmatrix} \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} \\
 &\quad - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} - \sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta (\cos \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha \sin \beta (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) \\ &\quad - \sin \alpha ((-\sin \beta)(\sin \alpha \sin \beta) - (\cos \beta)(\sin \alpha \cos \beta)) \\
 &= \cos^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta + \cos^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta \\ &= (\cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha)(\cos^2 \beta + \sin^2 \beta) \\ &= \boxed{1}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
shows  "det(matrix([[cos(alpha) * cos(beta), cos(alpha) * sin(beta), -sin(alpha)], 
[-sin(beta), cos(beta), 0], 
[sin(alpha) * cos(beta), sin(alpha) * sin(beta), cos(alpha)]]) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Calculate the determinant of the matrix 
\[
\begin{bmatrix}
\cos(\alpha)\cos(\beta) & \cos(\alpha)\sin(\beta) & -\sin(\alpha) \\
-\sin(\beta) & \cos(\beta) & 0 \\
\sin(\alpha)\cos(\beta) & \sin(\alpha)\sin(\beta) & \cos(\alpha)
\end{bmatrix}
\]
The final answer is 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes α β :: real
defines M : "M = Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j).
  if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then cos α * cos β
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then cos α * sin β
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -sin α
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then cos β
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 0
  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then sin α * cos β
  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then sin α * sin β
  else cos α)"
shows  "det M = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta \begin{vmatrix} \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} \\
 &\quad - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} - \sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta (\cos \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha \sin \beta (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) \\ &\quad - \sin \alpha ((-\sin \beta)(\sin \alpha \sin \beta) - (\cos \beta)(\sin \alpha \cos \beta)) \\
 &= \cos^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta + \cos^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta \\ &= (\cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha)(\cos^2 \beta + \sin^2 \beta) \\ &= \boxed{1}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes α β :: real
defines M : "M = Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j).
  if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then cos α * cos β
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then cos α * sin β
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -sin α
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then cos β
  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 0
  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then sin α * cos β
  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then sin α * sin β
  else cos α)"
shows  "det M = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Calculate the determinant of a 3x3 matrix $M$ where each element $M_{i,j}$ is defined as follows:

$M_{1,1} = \cos(\alpha) * \cos(\beta)$, 
$M_{1,2} = \cos(\alpha) * \sin(\beta)$, 
$M_{1,3} = -\sin(\alpha)$, 
$M_{2,1} = -\sin(\beta)$, 
$M_{2,2} = \cos(\beta)$, 
$M_{2,3} = 0$, 
$M_{3,1} = \sin(\alpha) * \cos(\beta)$, 
$M_{3,2} = \sin(\alpha) * \sin(\beta)$, 
$M_{3,3} = \cos(\alpha)$.

The final answer is 1.

 Evaluate

 &\quad - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} - \sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta (\cos \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha \sin \beta (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) \\ &\quad - \sin \alpha ((-\sin \beta)(\sin \alpha \sin \beta) - (\cos \beta)(\sin \alpha \cos \beta)) \\
 &= \cos^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta + \cos^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta \\ &= (\cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha)(\cos^2 \beta + \sin^2 \beta) \\ &= \boxed{1}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes α β :: real
defines M: "M \<equiv> matrix([[cos α * cos β, cos α * sin β, -sin α],

 *)

fixes α β :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). 
  if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then cos α * cos β 
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then cos α * sin β 
  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then - sin α

a_4.informal problem:
The determinant of a 3x3 matrix with entries defined as follows:

- The entry in the first row and first column is the product of the cosine of α and the cosine of β.
- The entry in the first row and second column is the product of the cosine of α and the sine of β.
- The entry in the first row and third column is the negative sine of α.
- The entry in the second row and first column is the negative sine of β.
- The entry in the second row and second column is the cosine of β.
- The entry in the second row and third column is 0.
- The entry in the third row and first column is the product of the sine of α and the cosine of β.
- The entry in the third row and second column is the product of the sine of α and the sine of β.
- The entry in the third row and third column is the cosine of α.

is equal to 1.

theorem
fixes α β :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. M $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then cos α * cos β else
                                if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then cos α * sin β else
                                if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -sin α else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then cos β else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 0 else
                                if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then sin α * cos β else
                                if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then sin α * sin β else
                                cos α)"
shows  "det M = 1"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} \cos \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \sin \beta & -\sin \alpha \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta \begin{vmatrix} \cos \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \sin \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} \\
 &\quad - \cos \alpha \sin \beta \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & 0 \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \cos \alpha \end{vmatrix} - \sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \\ \sin \alpha \cos \beta & \sin \alpha \sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= \cos \alpha \cos \beta (\cos \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha \sin \beta (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) \\ &\quad - \sin \alpha ((-\sin \beta)(\sin \alpha \sin \beta) - (\cos \beta)(\sin \alpha \cos \beta)) \\
 &= \cos^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta + \cos^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \sin^2 \beta + \sin^2 \alpha \cos^2 \beta \\ &= (\cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha)(\cos^2 \beta + \sin^2 \beta) \\ &= \boxed{1}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes α β :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. M $ i $ j = (if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then cos α * cos β else
                                if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then cos α * sin β else
                                if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -sin α else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then cos β else
                                if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 0 else
                                if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then sin α * cos β else
                                if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then sin α * sin β else
                                cos α)"
shows  "det M = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix M with elements defined as follows: 

- The element at the first row and first column is cos(α)cos(β)
- The element at the first row and second column is cos(α)sin(β)
- The element at the first row and third column is -sin(α)
- The element at the second row and first column is -sin(β)
- The element at the second row and second column is cos(β)
- The element at the second row and third column is 0
- The element at the third row and first column is sin(α)cos(β)
- The element at the third row and second column is sin(α)sin(β)
- All other elements are cos(α)

Prove that the determinant of M is 1.
